FINANCIAL SECRETARY
(INCORPORATION) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.05a.m.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    At present, the Chief Secretary holds property, both movable and immovable, on behalf of the Government by virtue of the Chief Secretary Incorporation Ordinance, which is Chapter 54 of the laws. The office of the Chief Secretary will cease to exist in its present form on the coming into force of the new Constitution, and it will therefore be necessary to make other provision. It is considered that, following the change made by the Federation, it will be more appropriate to have the necessary corporate body in the Treasury. This Bill therefore seeks to incorporate the Financial Secretary and to provide for the vesting in him as a corporate body of the properties now held by the Chief Secretary Incorporated. This will mean that on the introduction of the new Constitution the corporate body will be the Minister charged with responsibility for finance.

    The Bill itself follows, in the main, the provisions of the Chief Secretary Incorporation Ordinance. There is, I think, only one new provision to which I need draw attention, and that is in clause 5 (3) where it is proposed that there shall be power to vest property in a public officer or authority, that is in some person other than the Financial Secretary, should the need arise. It may occasionally be more appropriate that some other person, perhaps the Commissioner for Lands, should hold certain types of property. A similar provision appears in the Federation where they have it, mainly I believe, for the better administration of the railway. It is not inconceivable that some such power might be needed in Singapore at some future date.

    Sir, I beg to move.

FOREIGN JUDGMENTS
(RECIPROCAL ENFORCEMENT)
BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.13 a.m.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency's consent to the further stages of this Bill being proceeded with, and I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 2189



    At present, the only statutory provision for the enforcement in Singapore of judgments obtained outside Singapore is contained in the Reciprocal Enforcement of Judgments Ordinance which applies only to judgments obtained in the United Kingdom and those parts of the British Commonwealth to which its provisions have been extended. It provides that the person who has obtained a judgment in such territory may apply for registration of the judgment to the High Court, whereupon the Court may, if in all the circumstances of the case it thinks that it is just and convenient so to do, order that the judgment be registered and thereby become enforceable as if it were the judgment of the Singapore High Court.

    This Bill now before the Assembly goes further in that it applies not merely to countries within the Commonwealth but to foreign countries where reciprocal provision has been made for the enforcement of Singapore judgments. It follows very closely the provisions of the United Kingdom Act of 1933 and lays down detailed provisions relating to the registration of foreign judgments, with provision for its extension where substantial reciprocity is assured.

    Another important difference in the procedure will be that where the provisions apply judgments shall be registered by the Court if certain prescribed conditions are satisfied. The Singapore Court must in certain cases register judgments and thereafter enforce them as though they were its own.

    It is not, of course, possible at this stage to say to what foreign countries this Bill when enacted will be applied, but it is a most useful first step in giving Singapore citizens the right to enforce here judgment that they have obtained elsewhere, and in a trading community such as this, I consider this Bill to be a most useful and progressive step.

    Sir, I beg to move.

LAWS OF SINGAPORE
(MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL

10.20 a.m.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency's consent and recommendation that this Bill be proceeded with, and I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Bill, Sir, seeks to make certain necessary amendments in various Ordinances - 17 in all. Some of these are consequential on the enactment of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958. Of the constitutional amendments there are three, and they are contained in clauses 3, 8 and 10. Clause 3 is self-explanatory. It is designed to repeal the Governors Ordinance.

Column: 2191



    Clause 8 makes members of the Public Service Commission "public servants" within the meaning ascribed to that expression in the Penal Code. At the present time, the Public Service Commission Ordinance does this, but that Ordinance will be repealed in due course by the Constitutional Order in Council which, by Part IX, will replace the existing Ordinance; but it is not correct to put in an instrument like the Constitutional Order in Council the protection that is proposed to be given by clause 8 of this present Bill.

    Clause 10 is designed to amend the Criminal Procedure Code to give effect to paragraph 32 of the Report of the Constitutional Conference held in London in 1957 and published as Sessional Paper No. Misc. 2 of 1957. It was there agreed that while the decision to request the assistance of the British forces, or forces of Her Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom, in aid of the civil power would rest with the Singapore Government, Her Majesty's Government would retain the ultimate discretion as to whether, how and to what extent such a request should be acceded to; and to give effect to that, it is desirable to amend the Criminal Procedure Code by the insertion of a new section as is proposed by clause 10 of this Bill.

    Sir, the opportunity has been taken to make some other corrections and amendments to our law. Clause 2 is a comparatively minor matter. It corrects the Reciprocal Enforcement of Maintenance Orders Ordinance to take account of the new status of the Federation of Malaya.

    Clauses 5, 6, 13 and 17 delete provisions of the law which are now spent, and clauses 4, 11, 12, 14 and 16 rectify inadvertent omissions from the Legislative Assembly (Presentation of Subsidiary Legislation) Ordinance, 1958, which hon. Members will recall was a Bill with a very long Schedule amending, I think, over 70 Ordinances to bring their provisions into line with

Column: 2192

the existing Standing Orders and practice of this House in relation to the presentation of subsidiary legislation.

    Clause 7 of this Bill merely corrects something that was inadvertently overlooked in 1955 when the laws were revised, and clause 9 amends the Children and Young Persons Ordinance to remove the conflict between an existing provision in that Ordinance and the Criminal Procedure Code regarding the age below which a person may not be sentenced to death.

    Clause 15 makes an amendment to the Road Traffic Ordinance rendered necessary by the present system of staggering the periods for the issue of vehicle licences by the City Council. At present, the period of grace is one month, which worked quite well when licences were issued twice a year, but now that licences are issued twelve times a year, it is desirable to shorten this period so as to avoid any overlap.

    Clause 18 makes a drafting amendment to the recently enacted Police Force Ordinance, 1958, which, on the coming into force of the new Constitutional Order in Council, ought to be worded slightly differently to make the position abundantly clear with regard to the powers of the Public Service Commission vis-a-vis recommendations from the Commissioner of Police. At the same time, it is proposed to amend in three Ordinances references to the Police Force Ordinance, 1941, which will become inaccurate when the Police Force Ordinance, 1958, is brought into force.

    Hon. Members will notice that the first clause of this Bill provides for its coming into operation on a date to be appointed. Some of these changes are essential preparatory steps to the smooth introduction of the new Constitution, and the date of the coming into operation of this Bill will, no doubt, be linked with the date for the coming into force of the new Constitution.

ESTATE DUTY (AMENDMENT)
BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.36 a.m.

    The Acting Financial Secretary (Mr Oon Khye Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the Governor's recommendation to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this Bill introduces two important changes in the law which are considered desirable in the light of experience in the administration of the Ordinance, both here and in other countries. The first change proposed is that gifts of property should be deemed to be part of the property of the deceased at his death for the purpose of liability to estate duty if made within five years of the death of the deceased, instead of the present three years as provided in section 7 of the Ordinance as it stands. This change is effected by clause 4 of the Bill. Clauses 5 and 6 are consequential amendments. It is quite legitimate for a person during his lifetime to make a disposition of his property with a view to evasion of estate duty on his death. The object of these provisions of the Ordinance is to stop such a loophole. It has been found that the present era of three years is too short to be effective in preventing evasion of duty; both in the United Kingdom and Ceylon, the period has been extended to five years. A similar amendment has recently been introduced in Hongkong.

    The second change, effected by clauses 7 and 9 of the Bill, seeks to remove what is considered to be a defect in the law relating to the assessment of estate duty. Under the existing law in sections 38 to 40 of the Ordinance, no transaction in any of the property contained in the estate of a deceased person can take place unless evidence is produced that the estate duty has been paid. But there is no direct obligation laid upon the executor or administrator or other accountable person to submit to the Commissioner of Estate Duty an estate duty affidavit relating to the duty payable; and in practice no such action is taken until it is intended to transact with the

Column: 2196

property. The result has often been delay in payment of duty and in some cases even non-payment. It is now proposed to make it obligatory on the executor or other accountable person, as defined in the Ordinance, to submit an estate duty affidavit within six months of the death of the deceased, and at the same time to give the Commissioner power to assess the estate duty payable in any case where he considers it desirable.

    Both these new provisions are based on similar provision contained in the Ceylon legislation, and will bring estate duty practice more or less in line with income tax practice.

    Clauses 8, 10 and 11 of the Bill introduce various consequential amendments. Clause 12 introduces two new sections containing formal provisions relating to certificates and notices issued by the Commissioner under the Ordinance.

    The Rubber Regulation Ordinance was enacted before the war, and it was necessary in the 1930's, during the years of trade depression when there was over-production of rubber and the price of rubber had dropped to a very low level. This Ordinance enforces limitation of rubber production in both large and small estates by the issue of coupons or grants of credit for permitted production after due assessment has been made of the holdings in each quarter.

    It also regulates the sale of rubber lawfully produced under the terms of this Ordinance, as well as the import and export of rubber, except under prescribed conditions.

    Since the war, as hon. Members are aware, control over the production of rubber has not been exercised, nor is there any international agreement over production between rubber-producing countries, and as a result the provisions of this Ordinance have not been administered. The Ordinance has not, however, been repealed previously because of the necessity to keep in force the provisions of section 11 of the Ordinance setting up the Malayan Rubber Fund and the Advisory Committee for the administration of the Fund. This Fund and the Advisory Committee were in existence until 15th January, 1959.

Members will recall the primary purpose of the provisions of Part III of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance was to give effect to an arrangement with the Federation of Malaya for the regulation and control of the Straits of Johore in order to prevent the movement of persons and supplies designed to assist the Communist terrorists in the southern part of that State. With the gratifying success which has been achieved by the Federation authorities in the campaign against the Communist terrorists, it became possible at the end of last year for the whole of Johore State, adjacent to Singapore Island, to be declared a "white" area, and with the agreement of the Federation of Malaya Government,

the Johore Straits Control Scheme terminated on the 31st December. It is consequently no longer necessary to maintain the provisions of this part of the Ordinance which confer the legal powers to implement that Scheme.

    There are, however, two other matters covered by this part of the Ordinance. The first is the creation of the Port of Singapore North and the application thereto of certain provisions of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance. These matters are covered by sections 11 and 12 of the Ordinance, and in so far as the provisions are permanently required, they should more appropriately be embodied in the Merchant Shipping Ordinance itself. This is being effected by the Merchant Shipping (Amendment) Bill, introduced at the last sitting of the Assembly and which my colleague, the Minister for Commerce and Industry, will be putting through its remaining stages of the day.

    The second matter relates to certain restrictions imposed on shipping using Telok Ayer Basin and the waters around Keppel Harbour, Pulau Bukom, Pulau Sebarok, and St. John's Island. These are dealt with in sections 13 and 14 of the Ordinance. Certain of these provisions have since been included in the Singapore Port Rules and are consequently redundant, whilst the security of the places listed in the Fifth Schedule to the Ordinance can, I consider, be adequately protected, where necessary, by appropriate declarations under the Protected Places and Areas Ordinance, 1955.

    It is accordingly now possible to repeal the whole of Part III of this temporary Ordinance, and I accordingly beg to move.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Sir, I move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill is connected with the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) (Amendment) Bill, 1959, which my colleague, the Chief Secretary, moved just now. This Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) (Amendment) Bill proposes, inter alia, the repeal of sections 11 and 12 of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance so as to put into effect the termination of the Johore Straits Control Scheme.
